item.title: R to @quant_arb: Appreciate any RTs on this. Feel free to share it to anyone you think would fit the role.

item.title:
Looking for a network / low-latency engineer for hft trading firm role.
Specifically, someone familiar with latency optimization on the network side, not the tick-to-trade (compute) side.
Ping with CV if interested in details (send photo of CV to DM, not link to PDF)
item.dc:creator: @quant_arb

item.title: R to @quant_arb: Probably not ideal for finding the actual latency as post-engineering you may have a significantly different number + matching engine latency will add a lot (esp true for the DEXs)

item.title:
RT by @quant_arb: How I handle data deduplication:
1. ONLY parse the metadata that is required to identify the raw event from the exchange. Depending on its kind, you can check if its an event you have already seen by its ID or timestamp
2. If its new data, then make sure its data that triggers an action in your system, otherwise throw it away.
item.dc:creator: @ninjaquant_
item.description:
How I handle data deduplication:

1. ONLY parse the metadata that is required to identify the raw event from the exchange. Depending on its kind, you can check if its an event you have already seen by its ID or timestamp

2. If its new data, then make sure its data that triggers an action in your system, otherwise throw it away.

item.title: R to @quant_arb: This is very specific to HFT. Otherwise just aggregate some Tardis quote data into midprice bars and call it a day.
item.dc:creator: @quant_arb
item.description: This is very specific to HFT. Otherwise just aggregate some Tardis quote data into midprice bars and call it a day.

item.title: Tardis is great but the best data is your own data. Only that data has the latency information that is important for HFT analysis. Otherwise you kinda just have to assume latency and hope it's a reasonable guess (often wrong conditional on wanting to trade - ie spikes when trade)
item.dc:creator: @quant_arb
item.description:
Tardis is great but the best data is your own data. Only that data has the latency information that is important for HFT analysis. Otherwise you kinda just have to assume latency and hope it's a reasonable guess (often wrong conditional on wanting to trade - ie spikes when trade)
